entry.title: Combined summary - merged multisig inputs
entry.summary: In 2015, Boris Neklabaro asked via bitcoin-dev if it was possible to merge two Unspent Transaction Outputs (UTXOs) spending from multiple Pay-to-Script-Hash (P2SH) inputs and if it was possible to combine inputs P2SH and Pay-to-Public-Key-Hash (P2PKH) in a single transaction. The answer to both questions is affirmative. Multiple UTXOs spending from various P2SH inputs can be merged, and it is possible to combine P2SH and P2PKH inputs in a single transaction because the signatures for separate inputs are entirely separate.To merge two UTXOs, both outputs need to be owned by the same address. Spending from multiple P2SH inputs is possible because P2SH allows more complex scripts to be used as locking conditions for transactions. This means that multiple P2SH inputs controlled by the same address can exist. Combining inputs from P2SH and P2PKH in a single transaction is also possible. P2PKH involves sending funds directly to a public key hash, but it is still a valid form of transaction even though it may seem less secure than P2SH.Overall, while merging UTXOs can only be done if both outputs are owned by the same address, spending from multiple P2SH inputs and combining inputs from P2SH and P2PKH in a single transaction are both possible within the technical framework of Bitcoin transactions.
